Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Story: This morning, I woke up to the sound of my husband reminding me that his relatives would arrive by noon. The house was a mess—dishes piled up, laundry scattered, and the living room needed dusting. As a wife, I felt the pressure to make everything perfect, to show his family that I could manage our home with grace. But just as I started scrubbing the kitchen counters, my phone buzzed. My salon client, a nervous bride-to-be, texted that she and her bridesmaids were already outside, an hour early. I glanced at the clock, heart pounding. As a hairdresser, I knew I had to greet them warmly, calm their nerves, and make their special day flawless. But the thought of leaving the house in chaos gnawed at me. My husband’s expectant look, the bride’s anxious messages, and my own sense of responsibility pulled me in opposite directions. I stood frozen in the hallway, torn between the roles I was supposed to play, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing down on me.
